description.text:
baufix building set

this is the most fun toy
the bolts should be printed in pla as it is a much more solid material than abs and not as easy to shear

i was going to add the bolts as sets of 12 but i have tried to print the bolts as sets with abs and have found out that the head of the nut shears from the threaded part real easily no mater what the infill is set to and the dim of the threaded part are larger than the design so it is best to print each bolt as 1 piece takes longer but they are much stronger and print accurately that way this just might be my filament but this is just a heads up if you try more than 1 at a time you might have better luck with pla in sets right now i do not have pla in the right colors but i will try when i get some

everything is exact measurements of the original parts except the wheel insert that is made so that the new wheels that you print spin on the insert as the original is of poor design and does not turn when the bolt is tightened

no supports are required for all but the rubber tires and wrench those are the only parts that require supports

the rubber tires can be printed in either flex or solid filament as the rim is in 2 parts like a truck tire

description.text:
Having been bitten by some clogging recently I decided to design a filament cleaner that fitted nicely on the extruder of my Mini. There are two pockets for the idler bolt nuts that I used to mount the cleaner on the extruder body. I added a drip of (IKEA) mineral oil to make sure all dust stays in the sponge.

update: I shaved a bit off of the studs to make them fit slightly better. I think you still need to file them down until they fit snugly though.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.250

Infill:

85%

Notes:

I printed it standing up using buildplate support because I wanted the inserts to have a bit more tensile strength. I cut one centimer of the short side of a scourer and keep the rubbing/green part of the sponge on because it isn't in the way for proper operation.
You probably have to file the inserts a bit to make them fit snugly.
Modified focus ring to better grip of gripthe lenses, had beter clearance for mounting screws and longer reach to adjust all the range property.

description.text: 0.2 is much better than 0.1, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207389 I got sick of printing xmas things and decided to have another crack at what I actually got a makerbot for -- making machines. I saw a diagram for a ratchet using BB's and springs which caught my interest, as it looks MUCH tougher than an all-plastic ratchet would be. The plastic spring part can be thick and tough, and doesn't need to move far at all. And the holding force doesn't get concentrated on the weak tip. You know the drill by now. This is an experiment, not a practical part -- even though I'm happy to say it works -- and if you want to use it yourself, get the OpenSCAD file and fiddle until happy.

The principle is simple enough. The ball bearings, four 4.5mm airgun BB's, fit in ramps in the middle. When you turn the ratchet one direction, they are rolled down the ramps and stay there. Turn it the other, and they get pulled up the ramps to push against the ring, causing more friction. It is a VERY tight fit. You need to compress the springs to make it fit with the BB's already inside, and the channels are a bit small for the BB's. The center hole is meant to fit a 6mm hex-wrench or 1/4" screwdriver hex-thing. Improvements I intend for the next one:
1) Cut away more material for a looser forward spin.
2) Deeper, wider notches for tighter backwards latching.
3) Wider ramp channels to fit the BB better. This needs util.scad to work, mostly for my radial() function.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

description.text: It's always good fun watching scuba divers deploy a SMB (Safety sausage) from 5 metres. Often there is line everywhere, and if you are lucky, you get to see them getting dragged to the surface along with the SMB. The solution is a drop reel. Connect one end to the SMB, drop the reel and let it spool out (5 metres of line). Then inflate the SMB and the line goes up cleanly.This tiny reel takes 5 metres of dive line (2mm VB cord). It goes in the pocket or attach it to the SMB. It has a 10mm threaded inner gap for a M10 bolt to make the reel negatively buoyant. Or a small fishing lead weight works. Safe diving

Used Ikea Led http://www.ikea.com/it/it/catalog/products/80302664/
and superglue for assembly.

title: Anet A8 X Axis Stabilization
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Anet A8 is a fun unit but it has a lot of problems that need to be tinkered with and improved. On my unit, I noticed that if I grabbed the metal U bracket that holds the extruder to the X axis and rotated it clockwise and counter-clockwise, that there was a mile of play and wobble. I knew that the bearings that came with the A8 are total garbage, so I first upgraded all three bearings on the X Axis with some quality German 8 x 15 x 24 linear bearings (Ina Model KH0824PP). I also replaced the 8mm diameter rails with two quality rails that I ordered from McMaster Carr (400 mm long-McMaster Carr part number 6112K45). Printer got quieter in the X axis and was smoother operating. That improved the printing situation a little, but there was still a problem. I found out with some research later that these type of bearings do allow a degree or less of movement to compensate for alignment issues. I figured that if I could stretch out the distance between the upper bearings, the mounting points on the X axis would be a larger triangle that would have less play. So I designed an extended pillow block, that can do just that. Thinking back, using bronze bushings might have worked also, but even with those, these blocks could be helpful. Because the blocks are extended and if you do decide to do this mod to your printer, you might have to tweak the X axis offset numbers in your software. Because the blocks are only extended by 2 cm, you still have full axis to the left side of the printing table and almost to the edge on the right side. The blocks separate the upper bearings by an extra 4cm over the existing spacing. After doing the mod, I found out that printing is way more even, especially in the X axis direction and have noticed a dramatic improvement in printing quality. You will notice MUCH less play in the head after doing this mod, and I will include a before-and-after picture showing the changes in the print. The print of the Z axis screw clamp was done before the mod, and the print of the elephant (for the kids) was made directly after. Big difference in print quality. Because the new pillow blocks barely hit the X axis limit switch on homing, and I did not like the way the wires routed to the switch, I have also included a quick design for an X axis limit switch mounting bracket. That bracket uses the existing mounting holes on the unit and you should have enough extra hardware in the kit to find two extra wood screws that are used to mount the bracket and the switch from the original materials. Lastly, belt tensioners are a must on the A8, and I am sure that one of the many designs available on Thingiverse will work in your setup. If you try this mod out, please provide your feedback and post your results as I am curious of your results! Now...onto the Y Axis!

FYI: I added four pictures. One is the diameter measurement of the Chinese made rail, the other of a McMaster Carr qualified rail. You can see that the Chinese rail is undersized by over .0015"! Also, two pictures of the diameter of a Chinese bearing vs the German one...the German bearing is oversized by almost .0025 and the Chinese bearing is just under 15mm. That is why the Chinese bearings slide right out of the pillow blocks once the C clip is removed. Who knows how close the hole in the blocks are...more tolerance everywhere...total junk but easy to upgrade with Ebay parts and just a few dollars.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed the switch bracket with 2 layer walls and the pillow blocks with 4 layer walls. .3mm height works great for both. The blocks were printed with the rod clearance hole (screw side of the block) down on the table without supports. The switch bracket was printed with supports initially, but has been redesigned to print without supports.

On the pillow blocks, you can chose to drill out the four mounting holes with a 9/64" drill and then self-tap the 4mm mouting screws into the block, or you can drill clearance holes and optionally use the hexagonal nut profile to retain a 4mm nut into the block. I used the self-tap method which worked fine, but might I might change the setup in the future. The nut feature was added in a later revision of my design after further thinking about the design.

comments.text: I believe that the stock shaft couplers are the main cause of the z-axis wobble. Flexing is not the problem. The main problem is caused by the coupling of the lead screw. I had about 0.020" run out on my lead screws at the coupling. The stock coupler pushes the shafts to one side of their bores by the set screws. This means that the shafts are no longer concentric with the bore of the coupler. This difference is the result of the tolerance of the OD of each shaft and the ID of the coupler bore. In theory, this should be the only cause of the run out between the two shafts. However, since the lead screw has threads, the set screws will try to locate in the thread grooves when tightened. This causes the coupler to become cockeyed and this angle depends on the tolerance of the OD of the lead screw and the ID of the coupler. What is needed is a coupler that doesn't use set screws but uses screws to clamp down on the bores to shrink down their diameter to the diameter of the shafts. That is what this coupler mentioned does. After I installed some metal flexible couplers that clamp down on the diameter, the measured run out on each Z lead screw at the coupler is now less than 0.003" and I have no wobble problems.
comments.author: boopie

comments.text: did you design the coupling for the threaded rod or did you find it here?
comments.author: Ski12568

comments.text: I found it on here. It makes a difference because the standard coupling is not rigid.
comments.author: Ski12568

comments.text: The standard coupler is used to eliminate tolerances of the z axis threaded rod. I whould not fixate them, expecting you have a perfect straight rod and motor.
comments.author: danohpsp

comments.text: Trust me, if you align the Z axis rods properly, you can fix the Z axis threaded rod to the motor and get better prints.  The standard coupler can jump up with vibration really easily throwing off layers.  When you purchase a real Prusa model, the threaded rods are welded directly on the motor shaft because of this.
comments.author: butchja

title: ArduBoard - Arduino and Breadboard on one Board!

description.text:
Have you ever tried carrying an Arduino connected to a breadboard? It's a delicate operation! Wires popping out of the breadboard, connections disappearing into space,...
That's why I designed and built this simple board witch keeps your *Duino connected to the breadboard and your project safe.

Basically it's just a piece of Plexi with 6 holes in it.
You can cut it with a Lasercutter, a CNC mill or just the old way by drilling and sawing.
Most of the breadboards have an adhesive, so you can just stick them onto this board.
And the Arduino is just bolted down with short screws and spacers. Every standard Arduino should fit. Enjoy!

title: Soldering workplace - magnetic holders and baseplate design

description.text:
Soldering workplace

I was inspired by my neighbour's solution for holding PCBs while soldering but I saw some flaws and wanted to make it a bit better and smoother.

PCB Holders

I wanted more options to hold PCBs while soldering so I made grooves for flat, straight UP 90° and two 45° grooves for better access to bottom side.

Bowls for SMD parts

While not really necessary sometimes it may be useful to have fixed place for small components.

Spool holder

I have put a lot of thoughts to these, I wanted something sturdy and scalable and yet simple. Good feature thanks to those two cones is that you can fit almost any spool and have it perfectly centred between holders. Also if you print more cones you can easily extend this holder to hold multiple solder spools or wire spools too. So it is scalable. Then just get M8 gate screw which has screw-thread only at the end of it. Some washers and M8 nuts and you are all set. There is no need for bearings as 3D printed plastic is usually very smooth so it runs well.

Magnets

I have selected 2 types of magnets for all the parts. They are of these dimensions.

Ø10x4mm rounded neodymium magnet with magnetic force of 2.1kg each
6-12 pieces for spool holders (depends on how strong you want it to be)
2 pieces for each PCB holder

Ø20x1mm for each SMD bowl, I got ones with 3M tape

Steel base plate

My neighbour has komaxit coated (powder coated) steel sheet ca. 2mm thick. At first I wanted to go this route as well but I found it very hard to get smaller piece of steel sheet and I didn't want to buy the whole 2000x1500mm sheet for just smaller size one. Then I found company who for relatively cheap offer laser cut sheets of multiple metal types and sizes. So I decided to go with stainless steel 250x250x2mm and also with rounded corners to make it nicer and if I exclude shipping this was just $7 which is great.

For Czech makers among you this is the link where you can get it too: http://plechynamiru.cz/kalkulator.html

Source files

I have designed these in Tinkercad so. If you wish to fork this design, go to these links.

PCB Holders and Bowls - https://tinkercad.com/things/bFa8cTCUAls
Solder spool holder - https://tinkercad.com/things/lwbivb4EkCe

Possible improvements

PCB holder spacers - just a piece of 3D printed something that will allow for fixed higher position of those holders. Or maybe something that with combination with screws will make it adjustable. If I come up with something I will definitely add it to this design.
LED lamp - I'm thinking about articulating LED lamp similar to what Darbin Orvar made but with 3D printed magnetic base to also house all electronics in.
Fume extractor - Simple 3D printed FAN holder with carbon filter and magnetic base.

When I have update to this Thing I will definitely add it here.

I hope you will like this design as I do. If you decide to print this out, please share your makes, it will make me really happy ;).

title: Robo 3D Adjustable X carriage w/removable adjustable double fan

description.text:
EDIT: 11/16/2017
Added newer (much better) fan to this Thing.
Update: The bearings I installed on the Y axis mod are still in use. So, I think the problem was that I tightened them too tight and broke the bearings eventually. Everything works well with them just barely snug.

EDIT: 11/15/2017
Redesigned the fan again. This one is much better!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2648964

EDIT: 8/27?2017
I designed a better fan for this mod right here>> DELETED!

EDIT: 04/22/2017
I ordered bearings from E3D and so far they are working great! So just forget the cheap stuff and get these.
http://e3d-online.com/623ZZ?search=M-BEARINGS-623

WARNING: SNUG only! If you make them too tight the bearings will fail. At least that was my experience...

I made an adjustable Y bearing block for my Robo3D http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2047143 and it has worked very well so I decided to do the same for the X. Not only will it allow you to adjust the bearings if they ever get loose you no longer have to use any grease! I hated grease because everything would stick to the grease and pull it right into the bearings. No more! Another benefit I see is that when I want to work on the x carriage I don't have to disassemble the whole printer. Just undo the adjustable bearings and lift it strait off! So far I am very happy with both the X and Y adjustable parts.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 or .3

Infill:

Solid for bearing blocks and 30% for carriage

Notes:

as with my Y blocks I have made changes after I made and installed the versions I'm using. I used metal tape again to hold the nuts in so they don't fall out during installation.
I printed the carriage at 30% but may end up printing it solid at some point because I have active heating for the enclosure (thats why the water cooling as well) and I think the part "might" warp with only 30%. Time will tell.
I had to be strategic as to where to place support when printing the fan part. I manually added support to the inside ring part that doesn't touch the bed and left out any support on the inside of the ring part. If not I would end up breaking the part before getting the support out of it.
Also just uploaded a revised version with longer clip to hold it to the carriage better.

NOTE:
After having one of the cheap bearings fail on me pretty quickly I am upgrading them to these. https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-10PCS-3X10X4mm-S623-2OS-CB-ABEC7-LD-3x10x4-Stainless-steel-hybrid-ceramic-ball/32596349454.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.qj8K6t

NOTE:
I've been running the Y axis blocks for about a month now and I have yet to have to adjust them at all. Both Y and X axis's are still using the cheap steal bearings in initially installed. Thus far the Y axis has had no problems with these cheap bearings but as I mentioned in the X axis Thing post one of those had went bad. I'm still running it like this until my new ones arrive. There is a clicking now and then and I believe it has been the reason for a missed step from time to time so I'm looking forward to seeing how the hybrid bearings do.

When installing these I didn't tighten them much at all! Barely snugged them up and they have been great ever since. I think the extra money spent on the better bearings will be worth it in the long run.

title: Mockup of MakerBot Replicator 2/2X Stepper Motor

description.text: Sometimes you want to do an upgrade, but you don't want to tear down the setup of your Replicator gantry.  Here is a fairly accurate mockup of the Moon Stepper Motor used on the extruders of the Rep 2 and 2X.  It comes in both a plain version, and with the feeder gear attached.

This stepper motor mockup is designed to be built in ABS. The suggested settings are: Scaling: 101.1% Resolution: Standard
Raft: None
Support: Left extruder (if available)
Platform temp: 115C
Extrusion temp: 230C Since I have a Replicator 2X, I use the Left Extruder for support, and use HIPS, as it comes off easily, and without having to use citrus products. I build directly on the Kapton tape of the platform, which gives the build a polished surface. For this reason I would set the model in MakerWare with the back end down on the platform (see photo). I find the adhesion very good, and I use an inverted can of compressed air to freeze the model, and a wooden handle to knock the model off the platform when done. In MakerWare the 101.1% Scaling is to make up for ABS shrinkage. I would not use a temperature higher than 230C for the extrusion, as the ABS may sag on the vertical shaft, causing deformation. The through-holes of the model are not threaded for M3 machine screws, as the prototype is, but this could be changed using the SolidWorks files. If any changes are made, they should be checked out in a program like netfabb.

remixed_from.author: supasorn
remixed_from.title: Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula)

description.text:
A reinforced version of the original duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850163) by supasorn, made after mine broke while I was installing the fans.

Changes:

  • Thickened outer wall of ducts from ~0.5mm to ~1.5mm
  • Thickened main brace by 2mm (requires longer screws, or using the (untested) inset screw model)
  • Added and modified fillets in several places to increase part strength

All internal dimensions are the same, but it's much sturdier and has a lot less flex. It should work just as well as the original for cooling.

Thanks to supasorn for making the original and releasing the Fusion360 file!

Update:
Recessed hole version tested by oberkorn!
New photos, printed at 0.2mm layer height with fans enabled

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (doesn't matter)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print upside down!
Took 60 minutes (estimated 52 minutes) at 50mm/s regular speed and 25mm/s outer wall speed sliced by Cura. Probably fine to run faster, my printer just wasn't quite tuned up.
Mine printed much better with a raft but it should be alright without, given a levelled bed.

Used Fusion360 file from original creator, went back through the timeline and press pulled the duct outer walls, added fillets in a few areas, increased fillet radius in others.
See Fusion360 file to see exactly what I did!

remixed_from.author: SerxioSierra
remixed_from.title: Eachine TX01 TX02 FPV camera mount with double guard protection cover for Eachine E010, JJRC H36 or FuriBee F36 Tiny Whoop mini drones

title: Eachine TX03 FPV camera mount with double guard protection cover for Eachine E010, JJRC H36 or FuriBee F36 Tiny Whoop mini drones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is remix based on my previous "Eachine TX01 TX02 FPV camera mount with double guard protection cover for Eachine E010, JJRC H36 or FuriBee F36 Tiny Whoop mini drones" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954514 (Dec 9, 2016).

I adapted that design creating a new one to mount the Eachine TX03 FPV (first person view) AIO (all in one) camera besides to protect its antenna when is installed for creating the named "Tiny Whoop" mini drone using the frames of the models Eachine E010, JJRC H36 or FuriBee F36, that do not come with FPV camera.

As the previous design I combined the mounts and guards creating 18 different kits / files ready for print. If you prefer you can also download the parts separately.

Before inserting the camera into the mount, is possible that you need to cut a bit the black glue protection of the power wires (red and black) where they are soldered to the board, because they might have a vertical orientation that would difficult the correct insertion. With my TX03, I removed a bit this black glue protection and the wires are free to enter perfectly in the space for them of the mount.

To insert the camera into the mount, please insert firstly the left side rotating the camera and then the right side (with the lens camera in front of you), pressing down until camera touches the base. For accomplish this, you will require see the lower corners of the two electronic boards of the camera, moving and pressing the camera until fits correctly inside the space. When it touches the base it will fit perfectly and will not move. To extract it from the mount do it in reverse mode. You can bend the sides for ease the extraction.

For last, to get better result in the printing is mandatory to use a 0.4 mm nozzle or less in the 3D printer because the insertion guards holes have thin walls. All my printing tests were made using 0.4 mm nozzle and choosing 0.8 mm for shell thickness in Cura software slicer and a low printing speed.

This design is valid for Eachine TX03 FPV AIO mini cameras. However it is not valid for Eachine TX01 and Eachine TX02 FPV AIO cameras because they have different sizes compared to TX03. For TX01 and TX02 you can download a different mount desinged by me from Thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1954514

Due to the increase of the total weight of the drone using the Eachine TX03 camera with this mount I recommend to replace the factory motors with others with more power, like Chaoli 615.

title: AV to HDMI converter adapter for 3DR Solo

description.text:
If you use some camera that has only AV-output, you can use this kind of converter.

As you can see from pictures, this is not easy to build.

I found 15 cm flat cable, 25 cm miniHDMI - HDMI cable and AV2HDMI-converter from Aliexpress. I removed AV-plugs from converter, and soldered original Canon AV-cable directly to pcb. (This reduces weight)

Probably most difficult is to find proper connector to Solo accessory bay. Alternatively you can use some small and light power bank battery and usb-cable to give power to converter.

When you use for example Canon camera with AV-output, then use AV2HDMI converter and miniHDMI - HDMI cable.
If you use original Gopro camera, remove converter and miniHDMI-HDMI cable, and use flat cable. Look pictures.

Look also: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1521297

author: Jroemisch

description.text: Holds the external components for an RFID reader in a fairly weather resistant case.   This is my first upload.

Scale the print so that your RFID board will fit inside the space between the two halves. Screw the back plate to the wall. Screw your RFID reader to the plate. Drill a hole through the wall in the provided hole and run the wires to the RFID reader.  Wire it up.  Make sure it works now. I'd coat any exposed electical wires with some brush on electrical sealant to keep it from corroding.  Put a small bead of gorilla glue around the perimeter of the case, snap two halves together. Let glue set up and case should be fairly weather resistant.

Dividerless version of my previous cable management clip thing-a-ma-bob but designed to sit flat on a surface such as a wall for network cable management, 3d printer frame for tidy wires that won't get caught in stuff, etc.

description.text:
This is a cord-keeper for things like headphone/earbud cords. Because I like to wrap my cords in a modified 'roadie-wrap' (alternating over/under figure-8, folded in half), I didn't want or need a cord-keeper that was a spool, spindle, bobbin, or card. I created this to help keep my wrapped earbud cords nicely held together in my backpack.

Created in OnShape - https://cad.onshape.com/documents/cc742dee594226008b4902e0/w/009f51350b6fb6d8844f49be/e/79ed7b44ccb61d323e0d6736

Printer:

Tiko 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

Medium

Notes:

I printed mine from PLA (the filament shipped with the Tiko 3D) at 200C. I used the Cura3D slicer since the built in slicer from Tiko makes a raft mandatory and that would ruin this object. BUT - I didn't build any supports into the model, so make sure you turn on supports in your slicer software, because 3D printing a helix/spiral is very tricky otherwise -- this thing is ALL OVERHANG.

The first iteration (v1) of the clip was more like a "C" with a circular array of divots cut out of it, ostensibly to act like hinge points. But because PLA is so stiff (and I didn't have any flexible filament), it didn't really work that well and just snapped.
Next iteration (v2.0) was a helix with 1.1x wrap, mirrored on the vertical axis - vaguely resembling ram's horns. This cross-section of the spiraled component in this iteration was too small, however, making it too frail.
Iteration v2.1 was a beefed-up version of 2.0, but the spacing/pitch was too tight and my wrapped cords didn't easily fit into it.
Iteration v2.2 and v2.3 were tweaks on v2.1 - making the pitch wider.
Iteration v2.4 (the one I've uploaded) has a wide enough pitch to slip my cords into, an an extended central part w/ a little knob on the end to help retain the cords (almost like a beak).

description.text:
This is a corner piece for the D-bot bottom corner vertices. It uses the parameterized corner piece here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1543523

The original had 70mm of rail covered in each direction. I used I think 40mm instead. The original parameterized corner piece was monstrously large, so I trimmed it down to something more reasonable. I also made it so in each direction two screws were used instead of one in each rail slot.

The attached photos show this corner piece printed out in red eSun PETG and attached to my D-bot printer, and the remaining three photos show the original corner bracing that was put on the printer following the original D-bot plans. I was looking for a stiffer corner bracing for these corners that would also help with 90-degree alignment of the rails coming into the corner. This one-piece corner brace joins these rails into the corners with a nice tight joint that is much stiffer and stronger than the original bracing, and which enforces the 90 degree angles coming into the corner.

This file will make a brace that fits the left rear and front right corners of the D-bot. Use the mirror feature in Cura or your slicer of choice to make a mirror image of this that will fit the left front and right rear corners.

I printed this with:
.5mm nozzle
.24mm layer height
eSun PETG filament
245 C nozzle temp.
70 C bed temp
glass bed with a fairly old application of hairspray
Print speeds of 30mm/s for all walls and infill should be fine.

Update: I should mention that since these braces require that the rails slide into the holes in the brace, the exact build order that is shown in the D-bot build guide may need to be modified somewhat. I had already built my frame with the original D-bot corner braces, so after printing out these one-piece corner braces I had to partially disassemble my D-bot framework in order to retrofit it with these braces. Given how I did it after the fact I don't have a good description for the best build order. Print them out and think about it and I'm sure it'll be pretty clear how to order the construction to make this work well.

description.text:
In this lesson, you will use drag and drop coding to design a unique shape or pattern that you will then print on your 3D Printer. Hold your code in your hands as you go from "Code to CAD"

Coding is understood to help our students become 21st century learners that can not only interact with the technology around them, but also produce it. Not only do students gain a better grasp on how our increasingly technological world works, but also the computational thinking that is gained from coding education can help them in whatever career path they choose. In this lesson students will be able to practice computational thinking skills by being able to 3D print their code and interact with it.
NGSS CCSS

LEARNING OBJECTIVES
By the end of this workshop, the student will be able to:
• Design, create, and 3D print their code in the expression of a shape, figure or pattern
• Use TinkerCAD or similar CAD program effectively ESSENTIAL QUESTIONS
Use these questions to guide students understanding:
• How does block coding work?
• How does the turtle know what to do on the screen?
• What can you design using the blocks provided?

The following tutorial will walk you through using Turtle Blocks for a perimeter lesson. https://turtle.sugarlabs.org/ However, Turtle Blocks can also be used for -
Fractions, Spirograph, Measuring slopes of tangents, Trigonometry, Coordinate geometry, Vectors, Geometry and more. CCSS.Math.Content.3.MD CCSS.Math.Content.4.MD CCSS.Math.Content.7.EE Turtle Blocks is a “Blockly” type-coding tool where command blocks are strung together to create the code that the Turtle follows. Turtle Blocks has a low floor that allows your youngest learners to use it, but it also has a programming function for older students as well. The follow tutorial will demonstrate how a student will learn about perimeter. After having learned about perimeter of geometric shapes, students demonstrate their learning by drawing a shape with Turtle blocks that has a given perimeter. This lesson can be scaffolded to meet the following standards by changing the method in which students solve the given perimeter problem. To create the perimeter of a shape you will start with a blank screen edit screen and all of the main tools on the left-hand side. (Image 1) When you begin you will start with a “Start” tile that all future blocks will be placed under. (Image 2) The main tool to use is the turtle move commands. Within this tool bar you will find various command blocks with the primary ones being the move (forward, back), and turn (left, right) blocks. (Image 3) To start drawing the perimeter drag a forward block under the start command and put in a value. (Image 4) To turn the turtle drag a turn block, either left or right, and put in a degree value off of the direction the turtle is currently facing. (Image 5) Repeat this process for all sides, or you can also use the repeat function for multiple sides that are the same. (Image 6) As students finish their perimeter code they can move the turtle to see if their solutions where correct. If not, their ends will not meet up and they can go back, find the error, and fix the code. (Image 7) The last step is to drag the “No Background” tile to right under the start command. This will make your SVG image save only what the turtle has drawn, and not the entire screen. (Image 8) To save and print students’ designs you will need to choose "save project" and then ".SVG".
(Image 9) To 3D print your SVG image you can convert it into a .STL file in TinkerCAD, Autodesk Inventor, Onshape or similar 3D design tool. (Image 10) Image 1 Image 2 Image 3 Image 4 Image 5 Image 6 Image 7 Image 8 Image 9 Image 10
None (Sample File as needed)

Extensive tutorial on Turtle Blocks: http://wiki.sugarlabs.org/go/Activities/Turtle_Art

The following websites can also be used in a similar manner to Turtle Blocks, but are geared more towards higher level learners 6+

Beetle Blocks: http://beetleblocks.com/run/
Blocks Cad: https://blockscad.einsteinsworkshop.com/
Open J Scad: http://openjscad.org/

comments.text:
Hello, jstem.
In Turtle, one of the code blocks you can add to your code is the "save svg" block. When the Turtle programming gets to this code block, it will automatically format the path created by Turtle into a Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) file and download it to your computer. This svg file can be imported into 3D modeling apps like Tinkercad. When Tinkercad imports the svg file, it extrudes the 2-dimensional svg file's paths into a 3-dimensional solid.

print_settings.Notes:: Simplify 3D Notes:

description.text:
This object features Open in Customizer

You worked hard on your 3D Printer, CNC Mill or Laser Cutter and you want it to look good. You know that you can route the cabling through the extrusion slots and use covers, but the cable bundle looks a mess or could use some strain relief.

Use these parametric cable covers to tidy up your project and add strain relief for the cables. The original was limited to 16mm cable bundle for a Felix 3.0 printer. We've updated and coded it for many popular sizes (10, 15, 20, 30 and 40mm) and extrusion brands (OpenBeam, MakerBeam, MiSumi, AluTP, and what ever FelixRobotics uses). We also coded the object so you can specify any cable bundle diameter.

To use just download, or better yet open in customizer, and edit. Simply select one of the popular OpenBeam, MakerBeam, MiSumi, AluTP and even Felix Printer extrusion types. Then specify the cover body length, cable bundle diameter, and relief orientation. You can leave the rest at the defaults if you really want to get in and get making.

You can optionally change the tab gap finishing (square, circular, wedge, solid, or solid with cutout - aka fishtail).

You can also edit some advanced options for even finer control over the tabs and wall thickness, but it's strictly not necessary.

This is a brand new thing, and the list of extrusion types is not complete. If you message us, we can add your extrusion type to this thing.

Printer:

FelixPro1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Config Notes:
You can override the preselected extrusions using the the Manual Extrusion parameter tab. Please follow the directions in the Manual Extrusion Override section below.

Print Notes:
For best results print the cable cover/ stress relief on it's back with the tabs pointing up. That way the tabs will print cleanly. You will need supports with a overhang angle set to 45 degrees.

Suggest ABS for ruggedness, please let us know how other materials work out for you. Openscad may not completely close the shell, use Netfabb or other tool to repair any small problems with the generated STL.

Be careful not to make the tabs too thin as they will simply snap off. We suggest using the solid tab with typical or small clips. That way the tab won't just snap off.

Simplify 3D Notes:
Manually generate supports and remove the ridiculous supports just under the tab clips. We set the support angles to 60 and 30 degrees with a 30% fill so there is enough material for the part to stick and prevent the supports from falling over. To ensure that the part will stick to the supports set the horizontal offset to 0.05 mm. Otherwise the part will simply peel away from the support structure.

Cleanup

If you printed in ABS cleanup is easy.

Start with sanding the roughness caused by the supports. Finish by rubbing the outside with acetone lightly soaked paper towel. This will give a nice smooth but shiny finish.

Rubbing with fine sandpaper or toothpaste will take a bit of the shine off, if it's a bit too much.
Inspired by seaton's Cable Cover thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:277294. Modeled in openscad following his general design with some improvements.

Extrusion Profile Dimensions Step 1: Measure Profile

Using the above image as a guide, measure the aluminum profile:

  • Nominal Size: Profile nominal outside dimensions
    If the size is reported as 20x20 mm then the nominal size is 20 mm
  • Slot Width
    Width the cable cover tabs must fit into
  • Slot Depth
    Depth the clip would need to catch the back of the slot
Step 2: Enter Information

On the shown Manual Extrusion tab, enter the following information:

  • Manufacturer: Name of the company that produced the profile (optional)
    For example: "MiSumi", "AluTP", "80/20 Inc."
  • Name: Name or Series of profile given by manufacturer
    For example: "HFS8 Series", ""10 Series", "I52020"
  • Nominal size
  • Slot width
  • Slot depth
manual-extrusion Tab Step 3: Enter Information & Generate

On the shown manual-extrusion Tab, enter the following information:

  • manufacturer: Name of the company that produced the profile (optional)
    For example: "MiSumi", "AluTP", "80/20 Inc."
  • name: Name or Series of profile given by manufacturer (required)
    For example: "HFS8 Series", ""10 Series", "I52020"
  • nominal size (required)
  • slot width (required)
  • slot depth (required)

Now the object should generate.

Note: without a name your manual extrusion overrides will be ignored.

Console Snapshot Step 4: Forward Extrusion Information (Optional)

One last step that will improve this and future extrusion things - send your extrusion measurements forward to us for posterity! If you've done this on local copy of Openscad then there is a message on the console. A simple copy and paste will get it to us.

  • Go to the console and copy the information as directed. Don't get the ECHO: and the leading or tailing double quote characters ("), just the text between the quotes.
  • Now paste it into a browser address bar and hit return.
  • An E-mail message should be composed and be ready to go.
  • Send the message.
  • Thanks!

Edit the parameters to make the probe holder as needed. In Customizer the OpenSCAD code generates a cable cover for either vertical or horizontal cable entry.

The customizer and variables in the source are divided into general, manual-extrusion and advanced sections:

  • general

    • Diameter (mm)
      Diameter of cable bundle
    • Auto Length (yes/ no)
      Level body top with extrusion in vertical orientation
    • Body Length (mm)
      Length of cover body if auto length set to no
    • Orientation (horizontal/ vertical)
      Type of cable relief (horizontal: places tabs in line with body length, vertical: perpendicular to body length)
    • Extrusion (string)
      T-slot extrusion type
    • Tab Type (solid/ square/ circular/ wedge)
      Tab gap finishing between the fingers (solid: no gap - the tab has no separate "fingers")

  • manual-extrusion
    Use this section if none of the predefined extrusions will work for you:

    • Manufacturer (string)
      Name of the company that produced the profile (optional)
    • Name (string)
      The series or manufacturer's name for the extrusion (required)
    • Nominal Size (mm)
    • Slot Width (mm)
    • Slot Depth (mm)

  • advanced
    Normally just go with the defaults but alter at your own risk. Changes here may make unprintable parts.

    • Tab Clip (mm)
      Protrusion on end of tab that 'grabs' onto the inside of the extrusion track
    • Tab Thickness (mm)
      Tab finger thickness
    • Tab Width (mm)
      Tab width (in direction of tab placement)
    • Wall Thickness (mm)
      Wall thickness of cable cover
    • Resolution
      Line segments used to make a circle. Note the higher the number the longer the render will grind making your part. At "Insane" it may take longer than 45 minutes before customizer coughs up your part.
    • Undersize (mm)
      How much smaller to make the tab body for a good fit

This is the thirteenth revision (v0.8.6) that has implemented the following fixes since the original:

  • First beta realease, vertical cable relief only
  • Second beta release, added horizontal relief model
  • Fixed horizonatal relief model
  • Added tab tip trim
  • Added auto body length, this is best for vertical strain relief as it makes the body level with the top of the extrusion
  • Tab parameter tuning
  • Added circular and wedge tab seperation types
  • Reduced tab clip due to breakage, modified vertical hollowing for capsule due to breakthrough
  • Added solid tab, reduced undersizing for better fit
  • Added Manual Extrusion section to override preselects and generate console mailto: report
  • Added error message if diameter is too large for body
  • Added trimming interior portion of tabs
  • Added fishtail tab style for maximum slot wire bundle clearance

I do a lot of grilling and where I live everything is tank exchanges. You get an inspected tank every time, which is good! The bad thing is they use a 400lb gorilla to close the valve down before it leaves the blue rhino facility. Sometimes the valves are just tough even after you crack them open the first time. I made this wrench to give you a bigger better grip for unsealing those tough tanks. Magnets in the back let you stick it to anywhere on your grill when not in use.

Magnet holes are for 1/4" diameter 1/16" thick magnets. The holes are a touch oversized so something thicker could easily be used. I made test pieces and used them on 4 different valve handles. They were all a bit different, but this was sized right to work on all of them. If you come across a handle it can't turn, maybe increase scaling a few %.

title: Zahnstange mit Ritzel / Gear Rack and Pinion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parametrische Zahnstange mit Ritzel

Erzeugt eine Zahnstange mit Ritzel.

Schrägverzahnte Räder laufen ruhiger als geradverzahnte Räder. Sie erzeugen jedoch eine belastende Axialkraft, die durch die Achslager ausgeglichen werden muss. Empfehlungen für Schrägungswinkel abhängig vom Modul findet man in DIN 3978.

Bei gegebenem Modul m und Zahnzahl des Ritzels zr beträgt der Abstand zwischen Ritzelachse und Wälzgerade der Zahnstange
m⁄2·zr

Das Skript passt den Eingriffswinkel im Stirnschnitt an den Schrägungswinkel an, d.h. 20° Eingriffswinkel werden zu 21,17° im Stirnschnitt bei 20° Schrägungswinkel.

Format:

zahnstange_und_ritzel (modul, laenge_stange, zahnzahl_ritzel, hoehe_stange, bohrung_ritzel, breite, eingriffswinkel=20, schraegungswinkel=0, zusammen_gebaut=true, optimiert=true)

Parameter:

modul = Höhe des Zahnkopfes über der Wälzgeraden bzw. über dem Teilkreis
laenge_stange = Laenge der Zahnstange
zahnzahl_ritzel = Anzahl der Radzähne
hoehe_stange = Höhe der Zahnstange bis zur Wälzgeraden
bohrung_ritzel = Durchmesser der Mittelbohrung des Ritzels
breite = Breite der Zähne
eingriffswinkel = Eingriffswinkel, Standardwert = 20° gemäß DIN 867. Sollte nicht größer als 45° sein.
schraegungswinkel = Schrägungswinkel zur Zahnstangen-Querachse bzw. zur Rotationsachse des Ritzels; 0° = Geradverzahnung
zusammen_gebaut = Komponenten zusammengebaut (1) für Konstruktion oder auseinander (0) zum 3D-Druck

+++

Parametric Gear Rack and Pinion

Creates a gear rack and pinion.

Helical gears run more smoothly than gears with straight teeth. However, they also create axial loads which the bearings must be designed to contain. Recommendations for the helix angle depending on the module can be found in DIN 3978.

With a given module m and zp teeth on the pinion, the distance between the pinion's axis and the rack's pitch line is
m⁄2·zp

This script adjusts the pressure angle in the transverse section to the helix angle: e.g. with a 20° helix angle, a pressure angle of 20° becomes a pressure angle of 21.17° in the transverse section.

Format:

zahnstange(modul, laenge, hoehe, breite, eingriffswinkel=20, schraegungswinkel=0)

Parameters:

modul = height of the tooth above the pitch line = gear module = 25.4 / diametrical pitch = circular pitch / pi
laenge_stange = length of the rack
zahnzahl_ritzel = number of teeth on the pinion
hoehe_stange = height from bottom to the pitch line
bohrung_ritzel = central bore diameter of the pinion
breite = face width
eingriffswinkel = pressure angle, standard value = 20° according to DIN 867
schraegungswinkel = bevel angle perpendicular to the rack's length resp. helix angle to the rotation axis on the pinion; 0° = straight teeth
zusammen_gebaut = assembled (1) or disassembled for printing (0)

title: MendelMax 1.5 Adjustable Z Limit Switch Mount

description.text:
Merry Christmas to all!
If you'?re a MendelMax 1.5 from 3dprintertek.com owner this may make your Christmas for you!
For other printer owners this is a good concept to study for your own adjustable Z limit switch mount design.
As I said before the printer that I designed this for is a MendelMax 1.5 from 3dprintertek.com.
This is my answer for the limit switch mounts that come with the printer that are extremely hard to adjust. All you need for this is some hardware and your printer basically working.
On the hardware I'm lucky and have a good True Value hardware store in the neighborhood and also I'm an RC helicopter guy so some of it I had in my stock.
I have include the Solidworks files so if anyone would like to modify it feel free.

I tried to make the design as simple as possible but ran into some issues printing it.
The switch holder was originally a one piece design, but I was not happy with the way it printed even with support. The arm that holds the switch mount screw did not turn as well as I like. Hardware
1 x #2x3/16 Sheet metal screw
5 x M3x8 screws I used button head socket screws
5 x M3 nuts
1 x M4 Self-locking nut
1 x M4x50 screw (I got a Philips head one from True Value I had to change this to 55mm for new Hotend.)
1 x .25"x2" spring wire size 0.022" light spring
Or
1 x .22"x1.25" spring wire size 0.036" heavy spring I printed the parts as you see in the print layout. I used 3 perimeter loops with a layer height of .2mm and support. After printing check all of the holes for the correct size. The smaller vertical hole in the Z shaft clamp is threaded with a 4x.7 tap for the adjuster screw. The vertical hole in the adjuster clasp is to be a slip fit 4mm for the adjuster screw. If needed use a drill bit to clean out the remaining holes. Then assemble the adjuster clasp and the switch side clasp using the M3 screws and nuts. Check that the Z shaft hole will fit your shaft, use a drill to clean the hole. Be careful not to oversize the hole in the assembly it needs to slide on the shaft but not be loose. At the same time not tight on the shaft either, some drag on the shaft is ok. If the assembly is loose on the shaft you can take it apart and sand the mating faces and then reassemble and test on the shaft again. Use caution when sanding the faces, it will not take much sanding at all to tight it up. What I discovered on my printer was the Z shaft clamps cap screws were too long and were hitting the motor cases. So I replaced them with M4x10 cap screws. Now clean up the clamps with an X-acto knife. You may need to use a file to lightly clean up the Z shaft pocket before you can test fit the clamp. Again be careful not to remove too much plastic from the pocket. These clamps have to clamp the Z shafts tight so there is no movement or turning of the shafts. If you think the clamp is not tight enough you can again sand the face of the clamps to tighten them up. So let's put the whole thing together. Slide the adjuster screw into the adjuster clasp, add the spring, and thread the adjuster screw all the way through the thread hole in the clamp making it long enough to install the self-locking nut on the end of the screw.
I was not happy with the security of how the limit switch PCB fit to the switch side clasp with the one M3 screw and the knob. So I cut off the knob, fitted the limit switch PCB to the clasp with the M3 screw and positioned the PCB, and drilled a small hole in the clasp for the #2x3/16 sheet metal screw at the second mount hole. You can see this screw in the photo.
Mount the Z shaft clamp adjuster clasp assembly to the printer. With the switch PCB assembled to the switch side clasp install it on to the adjuster clasp with 4 M3 screws.
Reconnect the wiring, adjust and test.
That's it have fun and happy holidays!

title: Dungeon Dolls: Town Guard Captain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2/19/17

Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy Town Guard Captain includes a sword, embossed shield, pants with curved boots, an embossed shirt with pauldrons, plain head, and a plain base. I printed mine at 200% (Red) and the base stands at 56 mm tall. You can also print at 150% (Grey) which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, red printed at my library, grey printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini
The remixed and improved version of my 2014 work that was unprintable and abandoned shortly after inception

note
The shield comes in four variety's, two of which are included here. Embossed with a sunrise or not. Find more embossed shields and chest appliances here --> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073640

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

comments.text: Should these need supports?
comments.author: 3DPrintingLive

comments.text:
Depends. The area in the holes isn't so large that bridging should be unreasonable, but I use it mainly due to not having dialed in my settings yet and not knowing my bridging limits. The only piece I would say needs support is the one knight helm that partially goes over the eyes which isn't included on this figure.
TLDR: For the most part I've removed the need for support on the newer versions with pictures

description.text:
This is a 300 x 190 mm vacuum forming box. Included is the SketchUp file so you can resize parts as needed as well as take a look at how it all fits together.

Also included is a joint you can use to create a heat box. If you're using a heat gun, the gun alone will not evenly heat up your plastic. With a heat box, you can heat up your plastic faster and more evenly.

We printed the main sections in halves and friction welded them together. We also added feet that you can add hot glue to in order to give it some grip on the table. There's also braces inside the box to give the table extra support.

The box section with the vacuum port is included in two files. The box bottom and the bed top are single files that you must print twice each. You must also print the support twice and place them so it divides the box's interior into thirds.

For the heat box, we used foil tape on art store 5mm thick MDF board, 22mm PVC pipes, and the 3D printed joints included in this project. The PVC pipes were hot glued into place. 3mm bolts were used to connect the boards and the joints (holes were drilled in the MDF board).

We have already tested it and it works great with our Panasonic 1600 W - 410 W vacuum cleaner. Heat was provided by a 2000 W Stanley heat gun.

We're using HDPE sheets made from milk containers.

Vacuum forming takes practice and patience to master. Do some reading before you dive into it. Making your own hobby rig is so easy, with or without 3D printing, you should definitely try it before purchasing a larger, more complex system.

Printer:

ExtraBot 3020

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

low

Infill:

30-100%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the box sections with the vacuum port to prevent drooping. All other parts can be printed without supports.

Extensive friction welding is required to seal the box, add the feet to the bottom, as well as the supports inside. You could probably glue it, but we prefer friction welding.

For more information, please see this Hackaday article: http://hackaday.com/2014/12/30/3d-printing-technique-friction-welding/

comments.text: Printing myself now.  Maybe it would be a good idea to extend the holes for mounting it to the  T slots back to the end of the motor that way the tension from the belt wont as easily be able to pull the motor off 90 degrees. With the holes so far up front on the normal mount the mount bends slightly under the tension of the belt making the belt deform in order to engage the pully's teeth.  I am thinking about strapping the back of my motor to the printer frame with some zip ties to alleviate some of the tension.

title: Magnetically Attached Measuring Indicator Bracket For Solidoodle 3D printers

description.text:
This is a magnetically attached measuring indicator bracket used for precise bed leveling on all Solidoodle 3D Printers.  
The part that holds the electronic dial indicator is separate from the bracket so that you can design your own part for holding a different dial indicator.
The magnets are very powerful 8 mm rare earth magnets available from Harbor Freight tools for $2.99 for a pack of 10 magnets. http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html

The electronic dial indicator used for this design is a "Fowler X-Tread Tire Tread Thickness Gage" that reads either mm or inches. It is available from Global Industrial for $15.75. http://www.globalindustrial.com/p/tools/test-measurement/gauges-dial-bore-gauge-sets/fowler-x-tread-tire-tread-thickness-gage?utm_source=google_pr&utm_medium=cpc&utm_campaign=Dimensional-Measuring-google_pr&infoParam.campaignId=T9F&gclid=CLGO7rj2jbMCFcNM4Aod5RcAkg

ASSEMBLY:
Print one each of both parts. Carefully press the 8 mm diameter magnets all the way into the four holes on the back of the indicator bracket. The magnets will sit below the surface so the four motor extruder bolt heads are captured. Glue the two parts together using acetone (nail polish remover) as follows: Attach the "indicator_bkt_131217a_holder.stl" to the "indicator_bkt_131217a.stl" with the slot facing the indicator bracket. Carefully align the bottom of both parts while gluing. USAGE: Lower the Z stage (away from the extruder) to provide clearance for the indicator. Center the extruder. Install the indicator gage in the bracket. The assembly will now magnetically snap onto the four motor bolt heads on the extruder as shown. The assembly can slide a little on the bolt heads. I recommend pushing the assembly down gently until it contacts the sides the bolt heads. Proceed with the bed leveling measurements. Before moving the extruder in the X or Y direction, I recommend that the Z stage be lowered enough so that the indicator is not touching the print bed. Use a round number (10 mm) when lowering and later raising the Z stage.

Pompe à eau manuelle créée par l'association Togolaise 3B brique, bois, bio.
Cette association s'inscrit dans le développement durable. Elle développe un combustible alternatif, valorise les déchets de bois, préserve les milieux forestiers et favorise l'emploi des femmes et des jeunes. 
Si vous souhaitez nous contacter et/ou nous aider :
[email protected]
PayPal.Me/briqueboisbio

Manual water pump, created by the Togolese organization 3B (for “brique, bois, bio” in French, i.e. “brick, wood, organic”).
This non-profit organization is involved in sustainable development. 3B develops an alternative fuel, recovers wood waste, participates in forest preservation and promotes employment for women and youth. 3B was created by volunteers. The different parts are first produced in France and then assembled in Togo.
If you wish to contact us and/or to help us:
[email protected]
PayPal.Me/briqueboisbio

Description :
Cette pompe est auto amorçante, le tube PVC utilisé peut varier en diamètre et en épaisseur. 
En Europe les tubes PVC font 63 mm de diamètre extérieur et 3 mm d'épaisseur de paroi, mais il est possible d'en trouver d'une épaisseur plus faible, notamment au Togo.
Dans le cas de tubes de moindre épaisseur il faut compenser le jeu par le diamètre de la rondelle qui guide le PTFE.
Afin de faciliter l'amorçage il faut verser un peu d'eau dans la pompe par le trou de sortie.
Il est possible de remplacer les 2 rondelles imprimées en PLA, par des rondelles découpées dans des planches à découper en plastique alimentaire.
Le montage, coller le tube PVC sur la base avec une colle epoxy, le chapeau doit être démontable pour faciliter la maintenance. 
Utilisez du mastic silicone pour l'étanchéité du rejet d'eau, du tuyau de prise d'eau et du chapeau.
Le manche peut être recouvert d'un tube PVC de diamètre 32 mm.
Le clapet du bas, en chambre à air ou bâche de bassin est découpé à l'aide du gabarit. 
Le clapet se referme grâce au poids des rondelles et de la vis. 

Remarques :

Les tests d'impression de la membrane en "filaflex" ont été concluant. 
Toutefois, nous n'avons pas de recul sur la longévité des pièces imprimées.
Le coût élevé du filament et le temps de fabrication trop long nous dirigent vers la solution chambre à air ou bâche de bassin.

Voir le fichier PDF pour la quincaillerie.

title: Titanfall Smart Pistol Mk5 - Advanced Version for Lights and Sound

description.text:
This model cannot be converted into a working firearm and is a visual prop replica.

Using the excellent references from Ryan Lastimosa’s ArtStation page (the art director for Titanfall), I set about making a base model for the Smart Pistol, intending initially to make a very basic prop with a few LEDs. I spent about a week of my free time modeling the gun up, and in the course of doing so, the scope of the gun got more and more complicated. I just… kept adding to it. The final feature list contemplated for my ‘advanced’ version of the Smart Pistol is as follows:

  • Working safety paddle on side of gun to turn electronics components on and off.
  • Working audio effects via a speaker embedded in the barrel.
  • Working trigger to activate audio effects and other lights.
  • Illuminated sights and screens.
  • Easy battery operation, access, and replacement.
  • Working flashlight mount.
  • Working laser mount.

For a time, I considered trying to make the slide-action work on the gun, or adding a vibration motor to simulate the gun ‘kicking’ when firing, but I had to draw the line somewhere.

The gun breaks into five ‘main’ exterior shell components, with a number of other small, extra interior parts. This was built this way to make printing easier, so I could orient flat sides down onto my print bed and section it into smaller parts that would fit in my machine. There have been a number of interior channels hollowed out to accommodate the electronics I have planned.

For the sake of being thorough, here’s a comprehensive list of parts I believe will be required:

  • Adafruit 5mW 650nm Red Laser Diode
  • 8 Ohm 1W 30mm Magnetic Speaker (subject to change depending on performance)
  • Cool White Ultrabright 5mm LED x2
  • Flashlight Lens with Holder – “Dragon” Lens
  • MS12AFW01 SPDT Slide Switch
  • Mini Microswitch with Roller Lever
  • OS102011MS2QN1 SPDT Slide Switch x2
  • Adafruit Mono 2.5W Class D Audio Amplifier
  • Adafruit Audio FX Mini Sound Board – 2MB Flash
  • Arduino Pro Mini – 5V
  • WP1043YD LED Bar Single x4
  • 3x 3mm Green LEDs
  • 2x 3mm Red LEDs
  • Retraction spring, 5mm diameter, 10mm length
  • 121-0624/I-GR “I” 9v Battery Snap Contact
  • 9v Battery
  • An assortment of M2 screws of different lengths, between 8mm and 20mm long.

While I can gladly go on at length with images of how the gun’s designed to operate, I felt it would be easier (and more instructive) to record a brief video doing exactly that.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4HxFgBqwmtc

title: Pi-Cade printable on standard bed size
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my version on an Arcade cabinet.
I liked the overall design of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:980918 but it was too big to print for my printer and the parts I was planning to use were different too. so I decided to Remix it into the design I present today. I took the opportunity to remove the ugly screws on the side panels en the control surface of the original and made the whole thing a bit less like it was a design for panels using a CNC router and more like a 3D printer project. Unlike tghe original, all parts can be printed using a 20x20 cm print bed.

I´m provide the files "as is" and without full instructions however I´m convinced that with the help of the pictures it isn´t too difficult to recreate.

The mechanical parts:

  • Screws: M4 screws for the back, control panel and joystick mount, M3 for the rest
  • LCD panel: Makbies 7" (B) https://www.amazon.es/gp/product/B017SQ3J2Y/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • Raspberry PI 3
  • Joystick XSOURCE https://www.amazon.es/gp/product/B01LAUYCXE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • Audio amp.: https://www.amazon.es/gp/product/B017XCMJ92/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
  • Micro USB to pin adapter: http://www.ebay.es/itm/331743536245
  • Micro USB connectors http://www.ebay.es/itm/221818941334
  • USB Hub: http://www.ebay.es/itm/291741261016
  • Step up converter (to power the 12V fans from 5V usb power) http://www.ebay.es/itm/222305914365
  • Low profile HDMI cable (20cm) https://es.aliexpress.com/item/20cm-FPV-Dual-Up-Angled-90-Degree-HDMI-Type-A-Male-to-Male-HDTV-FPC-Flat/32709749259.html
  • 40mm fan for the raspberry
  • 50mm fan as case fan (on the back panel)
  • I used speakers from a broken laptop, you´ll have to find something usable yourself.

My person version features a WS2812 ledstrip controlled by an arduino mini pro but this is completely optional.
The PLA in the photos was bought from http://3dfilamentos.es (very good customer service)

Side, bottom, front and back panels: http://3dfilamentos.es/es/crystal-clear-iceland-blue-filament
Screen frame: http://3dfilamentos.es/es/filamentos-pla-luminous-yellow-transparente
Control surface and Top: http://3dfilamentos.es/es/filamento-pla-plata-premium
I also used a but of transparent PETG for the led defuser between the leds and the logo on the top.

The joystick is mounted from the bottom as I could not find any really short M4 bolts I used a longer bold with a nut. (see photo) a simular trick was used for fixing the screen frame and screen to the rest of the machine.

Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
These filament guides fit the guide tubes included with the Replicator 2X. They clip to the existing brackets that normally hold the tubes, so that the tubes are not pinched and give a gentler curve to the filament to reduce jamming during printing. They also reduce offset between rolls of filament and the entry into the guide tube.

I designed these after repeatedly having prints fail due to a "less than optimal" filament feed path. I hope they help others with similar problems.

The included pictures are in the following order:

  • 1st & 2nd: the new guides
  • 3rd and 4th: shows the original guide tube clips and the offset they can cause with a roll of filament
  • 5th - 7th: shows the new guides attached, how deep the tubes go into them, and the tubes inserted
  • 8th: shows the reduced offset between a roll of filament and the new guides

UPDATE 1

The ends of the rolling pin has be made thicker for easier use.
Supports were added due to the structure failing during printing without it.
The infill was lowered to save material. It hasn't been tested below 20% infill.
When opening into makerbot software, let the program rescale the object on the popup at start up.

I decided to take advantage of the 20x20 extrusions on my new Cetus printer by adding two tool holders. These make it easy to grab the scraper or allen wrench that came with the printer.

I would suggest printing these at 100% infill to give them the additional strength needed to twist the hammer nut into place.

I printed these at .2mm with no supports. The hammer nuts may need a bit of sanding or filing to make them twist into position easily depending on how your printer is set up. I wanted a very snug fit for my machine.

For the scraper holder, you can glue the pin into position or just insert it and use friction to hold it in place.
